newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Sri Lanka to tighten controls on effluent.
newsitem.headline: Sri Lanka to tighten controls on effluent.

text.p: Sri Lanka is to tighten controls on industrial effluent after the capital's drinking water supply was shut down after black dye leaked from a textile factory, the Central Environmental Authority said on Tuesday.
The government is to formulate colour standards in the release of effluent to waterways, authority's director general, Lionel Jayasinghe, said.

"So far, we have not had standards for colour in effluent," he told Reuters. "But we have taken serious note of what happened last week, and within the next two months, plan to formulate national standards for colour in effluent."
Colombo's drinking water supply was stopped on Saturday after a thick black dye was found in the Kelani river, from where the city's supply is pumped through a purification plant.
Government officials said the dye came from a textile factory in an export processing zone near the river.
They said the discoloured water was non-toxic but the supply was disconnected for about eight hours to clear the system.
The city's treatment plant could purify the water but could not remove the colour, explaining the need for colour standards, the officials said.
"An investigation has been launched and the factory concerned has voluntarily agreed to stop operations till it is over," Jayasinghe said.
He said regulations would be framed under the National Environmental Act of 1980 to ensure effluent was checked and treated for colour before being released into waterways.
